AF Silva Noelli, F
TI The geographical distribution of the archaeological evidence of the
   Guarani
SO REVISTA DE INDIAS
LA Spanish
DT Article
DE Guarani; archaeology; South America; territorial distribution
AB This work shows the geographical distribution of the archaeological evidence of the Guarani in southern Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay. The major goal is to prepare a map of the Guarani territories until the 16th century A.D. The data base, comprised solely of archaeological sites, is under construction. Historical data will be included in the future, to offer a synthesis of the settlement process and dynamics (including territorial expansions and retractions).

PT J
AU Roymans, N
   Heeren, S
AF Roymans, N
   Heeren, S
TI The archaeology of Roman period rural settlements in the Netherlands.
   Review of one hundred years of research.
SO REVUE DU NORD
LA French
DT Article
AB In this article, we present a picture of the development of the archaeology of Roman rural settlements in the Netherlands, from 1900 until today. The article aims to present the developments in the fieldwork (strategies, aims of research, institutions, scale) as well as the intellectual debates and topics of research concerning settlement archaeology in three periods. We will argue that the integration of the rural settlement archaeology and the military limes-archaeology in the Netherlands has led to the insight that the position of the settlements in a frontier zone of the Roman empire close to the limes caused a Romanization-process with its own specific properties.
C1 Vrije Univ Amsterdam, Archeol Ctr, NL-1081 HV Amsterdam, Netherlands.

PT J
AU Bown, W
AF Bown, W
TI The contribution of the archives to urban archaeology: Cambrai and the
   case of the Rue Saint-Martin (XIIIth-XVth centuries).
SO REVUE DU NORD
LA French
DT Article
AB Urban archaeology too often encounters quasi-insuperable obstacles, mainly as a consequence of the density of today's urban occupation. Written documents, archives, must then help it to understand the ancient urban occupation. Thus in Cambrai, in the rue Saint-Martin, archives allow us to draw a fairly accurate picture of urban implantation at the end of the Middle-Ages. Infrastructures and buildings can, indeed, be found in the ancient chirographs: a long and patient work allows then to position them again along the street. Sometimes even, richer documents lead to a more accurate reading of a site: one was thus able to produce a thorough description of the so-called "a l'Epervier" hotel situated in this same street. Consequently, and though they cannot in any way replace excavations, archives prove to be invaluable allies in the reading of the ancient urban grid.

   BRUYELLE A, 1850, MEMOIRES SOC EMULATI, V22

AU Hanoune, R

TI Archaeology in Bavay during the Second World War: The German records.
SO REVUE DU NORD
LA French
DT Article
AB Together with the annexation of the Nord-Pas-de-Calais and of Belgium after the defeat, a Nazi cultural programme for this region is established. The analysis of the German records for the period starting in 1941 testifies of an intention, finally short-lived, to have archaeological excavations carried out in Bavay by W. Unverzagt, and to have an air photography coverage of Belgium completed.

PT J
AU Sokolowska-Paryz, M
AF Sokolowska-Paryz, M
TI Diagnosing discourse: Poetry and cancer in Peter Reading's C
SO ZEITSCHRIFT FUR ANGLISTIK UND AMERIKANISTIK
LA English
DT Article
AB The paper proposes to analyze Peter Reading's C (1983), an entire poetic collection devoted to cancer and the ways of speaking about cancer. The significance of this work has been largely underestimated by critics, frequently hostile to Reading's innovative attitude to poetry, yet the collection remains unprecedented in its ambitions to highlight both the potential and the danger of any attempt to contain cancer within a chosen discursive structure, be it scientific or literary. The analysis of Reading's 'collection is embedded in a theoretical frame constituted by Susan Sontag's Illness as Metaphor, Michel Foucault's The Archaeology of Knowledge and the Discourse on Language, Jacques Revel and Peter Jean-Pierre's "The Body: The Sick Man and His History," and Clifford Geertz's "Ideology as a Cultural System." The thematic axis of the collection is constituted by the history of the poet-narrator's illness, though the narrative also includes stories of other cancer patients, as well as fragments from medical journals and dictionaries. The characters in the collection are distinguished not by individual personality traits but by the distinctive language in which they express their predicament. In relation to language that attempts to appropriate disease, Reading creates a fundamental opposition between poetry (health and life) versus prose (Illness and death). This distinction explains why the narrator, who has cancer, chooses the form of prose units in order to express his predicament, but also "tries out" various poetic forms which constitute his desperate hold on life. Reading draws a similarity between the hospital surgeon and the poet - the former dissecting human bodies, the latter dissecting poetic kinds and poetic meter. Reading's narrator becomes ultimately the surgeon-poet, carrying out his experimentations in "amputated" rhetoric. It is precisely in this quest for a more down-to-earth, prosaic poetry that Reading is truly an inheritor of the war poets - in the case of both war and cancer, poetry must sacrifice its figurative potential, because any type of linguistic defamillarization of cancer destroys the true nature of the illness.
C1 Warsaw Univ, Inst English Studies, PL-00497 Warsaw, Poland.
RP Sokolowska-Paryz, M (reprint author), Warsaw Univ, Inst English Studies, Ul Nowy Swiat 4, PL-00497 Warsaw, Poland.

PT J
AU Budd, P
   Montgomery, J
   Evans, J
   Trickett, M
AF Budd, P
   Montgomery, J
   Evans, J
   Trickett, M
TI Human lead exposure in England from approximately 5500 BP to the 16th
   century AD
SO SCIENCE OF THE TOTAL ENVIRONMENT
LA English
DT Article
DE human; lead; exposure; archaeology
ID HUMAN TEETH; ISOTOPIC-RATIOS; PEAT BOG; CHILDREN; APPORTIONMENT;
   SPECTROMETRY; DEPOSITION; SEDIMENTS; POLLUTION; SCOTLAND
AB Lead concentration and isotope ratio data are presented for the tooth enamel of 77 individuals buried in England and spanning approximately 5000 years from the Neolithic until the 16th century AD. Whereas other tissues may be affected by diagenesis in the burial environment, the Pb concentration of tooth enamel is directly related to childhood exposure. This record is preserved post-mortem and over archaeological time. Tooth enamel Pb concentrations in the prehistoric period appear to be variable within the range 0.04 to similar to0.4 ppm, with occasional higher levels. The Romano-British and medieval periods show a marked increase in Pb exposures with enamel concentrations reaching up to approximately 40 ppm. These exposures would today be associated with industrial pollution. Exposures appear to be highly variable compared with modem people, however, with many medieval individuals having very low enamel Pb concentrations comparable with prehistoric people. Lead isotope data refine this picture. We distinguish between the diverse isotopic ratios we believe to be characteristic of 'natural' exposure to Pb-from geological sources via the diet-and the much narrower isotopic range characteristic of exposure to technological Pb from ore sources. Taken together the data suggest that the maximum concentrations associated with 'non-technological' exposure at any period are similar to0.5-1.0 ppm, similar to that reported for modern people in England. (C) 2003 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Univ Durham, Dept Archaeol, Durham DH1 3LE, England.
